<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Organic revenue growth is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to net revenue, excluding the impact of currency, acquisitions and divestitures. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ongoing earnings per share is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to diluted earnings per share, excluding items. The term &#147;items&#148; includes the impact of asset
impairment, exit and implementation costs, primarily related to our restructuring program that began in the first quarter of 2004 (the &#147;Restructuring Program&#148;). These restructuring charges include separation-related costs, asset
write-downs, and other costs related to the implementation of the Restructuring Program. Other excluded items pertain to asset impairment charges on certain long-lived assets, gains and losses on divestitures, interest from tax reserve transfers
from Altria, the favorable resolution of Altria&#146;s 1996-1999 IRS tax audit in 2006, and other one-time costs related to our European Union segment reorganization. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Discretionary cash flow is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to operating cash flow less capital expenditures. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee also reviewed additional Kraft financial objectives, such as volume, operating income growth and operating income margin as part of their deliberations.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee also assessed, in the context of the annual incentive plan, progress against the following four strategic goals for 2007: (a)&nbsp;rewiring
the organization for growth; (b)&nbsp;reframing our categories to make them more relevant to consumers; (c)&nbsp;exploiting our sales capabilities; and (d)&nbsp;driving down costs without compromising quality. We publicly communicated these </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">34 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">strategies at the beginning of 2007. In addition, the Committee considered the well-executed transition of Kraft to a free-standing company following its
spin-off from Altria. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Consistent with the discussion above, the Committee also assessed the financial and strategic objectives for our North America and
International business units in determining annual incentive awards for Messrs. Searer and Khosla. Similar to the review of Kraft&#146;s overall business, review of the business units included the assessment of financial performance in areas such as
organic revenue growth, volume, operating income growth, operating income margin, discretionary cash flow and, in the case of Kraft North America, market share. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">In 2007, Kraft North America exceeded its revenue growth objectives and essentially met volume growth objectives, however, fell short on operating income growth, operating income margin and market share performance. The shortfall on
operating income growth and margin was primarily driven by the unprecedented record-high commodity costs, particularly dairy costs. The degree of difficulty in achieving each of these performance measures is challenging. For example, Kraft North
America fell short of its operating income growth and operating income margin objectives in each of the last three years and also fell short of organic revenue expectations in two of the last three years. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft International met or exceeded its revenue, volume, operating income and discretionary cash flow objectives in 2007. However, Kraft International fell short of its
operating income margin objective in 2007. Again, the degree of difficulty in achieving these objectives is challenging. For example, Kraft International fell short of its operating income growth expectations in one of the past three years and its
operating income margin expectations in each of the past three years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Based on these assessments, the Committee assigned business unit ratings to the
Kraft North America and Kraft International business segments and the entire Kraft organization. In 2007, the business unit ratings were as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="85%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="56%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Business Unit</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Rating</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft Foods Inc.</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">100</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">%</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft North America</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">90</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">%</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft International</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="right" COLSPAN="1" VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">115</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN="1" NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">%</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Business unit ratings for corporate employees are aligned 100% to the Kraft Foods Inc. rating. The presidents of
the business units (Messrs. Searer and Khosla) have 50% of their ratings based on the Kraft Foods Inc. performance rating and 50% of their ratings based on their respective business unit ratings. This alignment is meant to promote both
&#147;line-of-sight&#148; accountability as well as assure collaboration across the enterprise. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Individual Performance Assessment </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Individual awards are also determined based on individual contributions. Individual performance can range from 0% to 200% of the target award. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Following our fiscal year-end, the Committee assessed progress against all strategic objectives and other individual performance criteria established for each of the
named executive officers. The Committee then reviewed each named executive officer&#146;s progress against the criteria and determined the level and quality of each named executive officer&#146;s performance achievement. Based on that assessment,
the Committee determined an appropriate incentive award for the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and then reviewed and approved the incentive awards that the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer recommended for each of the other named executive
officers. Named executive officers that generally met all of the individual performance criteria received an annual incentive award at or near (+/- 10%) their individual target level, adjusted for the applicable business unit rating. Similarly,
named executive officers that exceeded their individual performance criteria received an annual incentive award greater than their individual target. Conversely, if a named executive officer did not meet many of his or her individual performance
criteria, then the named executive officer&#146;s annual incentive would be below his or her individual target and would likely be zero. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Additional
information regarding the manner in which individual performance was assessed for our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and other named executive officers in 2007 is provided under &#147;Compensation Paid to Named Executive Officers in
2007.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Annual incentive awards paid under this plan satisfied the performance-based requirements for deductible compensation under
Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code. Details with respect to tax deductibility of compensation are presented under &#147;Policy With Respect To Qualifying Compensation for Tax Deductibility.&#148; </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Long-Term Cash and Equity Incentives </U></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Long-term incentives are
designed to focus our executive officers on long-term operational performance that leads to superior sustainable shareholder returns. Long-term incentive awards have been delivered to executive officers through a combination of </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">35 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">cash-based long-term performance incentive awards (approximately 40% of the total long-term value) and restricted stock (approximately 60% of the total
long-term value). We will begin granting stock options as a regular part of our total pay-mix beginning in 2008. Changes to our long-term cash and equity programs are further discussed under &#147;Program Changes in 2008.&#148; The Committee&#146;s
2007 grant of a special stock option award to the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer is discussed under &#147;Compensation Paid to Named Executive Officers in 2007.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Cash-Based Long-Term Incentive Plan Awards </U></I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Long-Term Incentive Plan (LTIP) awards reward executive officers
for the achievement of long-term financial and strategic goals during the applicable performance cycle and are primarily designed to reward achievement of top-tier shareholder returns. Historically, Kraft&#146;s three-year performance cycles ran
end-to-end. This meant that a new performance cycle began only after the previous one concluded. Beginning with the 2007 &#150; 2009 performance cycle, we will run continuous overlapping performance cycles with a new three-year performance cycle
beginning each year. This significant change was adopted to allow us to adjust our targets more effectively cycle to cycle as business conditions fluctuate. This approach is most common among the companies in the Compensation Survey Group.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Transitioning from end-to-end, discrete cycles to overlapping cycles means that payout amounts will be appropriately adjusted downward so that payments
over any three-year period would be essentially equivalent to the amount paid under the former design. Because the first payment under this program will be three years from the date of this change, a transition multiplier will be applied to this
performance cycle. The transition multiplier is designed to assure that compensation levels remain competitive for executive officers who were eligible to participate under the previous end-to-end cycles. Newly eligible executive officers are not
eligible for the transition multiplier. The transition multiplier for the 2007 &#150; 2009 performance cycle is 183.3%. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The formula shown below is used to
determine actual awards for participants, including the named executive officers. Other than average base salary, each element of this formula is discussed below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Individual Target Percentage.</I> Each participant in the plan is assigned a target award as a percentage of the average of year-end base
salaries over the three-year performance cycle. Participants who are promoted into an eligible position, from a non-eligible position, are typically eligible to begin participating beginning with the next performance cycle. The target award
percentage may be adjusted during the performance cycle if an existing participant&#146;s role or responsibilities change. The Committee, after receiving recommendations from management, which are based primarily on competitive market information,
approves position-specific target award levels based on the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Target awards levels, as a percentage

<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Relative total shareholder return is a comparison relative to the Performance Peer Group during the performance cycle. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Target awards will be paid based upon achievement of the performance measures. The objective set for relative total shareholder return is for our total shareholder
return between fiscal year 2007 through fiscal year 2009 to be at the median of the Performance Peer Group. The organic revenue growth, ongoing operating income growth and cumulative discretionary cash flow targets were set based on our three-year
strategic plan. The degree of difficulty in achieving the internal measures is challenging. For context, we have met or exceeded our revenue growth objectives in only one of the past three years. Operating income growth and discretionary cash flow
objectives have not been achieved in any of the past three years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee may exercise positive or negative discretion in determining a rating,
including factoring in a qualitative review of the following unweighted metrics: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Talent development. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Equity Compensation
</U></I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee uses equity awards to align the interests of our executive officers with those of our shareholders. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Restricted Stock.</I> Since 2003, the Committee has granted equity awards to the named executive officers in the form of restricted stock. The Committee determined
that restricted stock is an appropriate form of equity compensation because it: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Directly builds executive stock ownership and aligns the interests of management with those of shareholders; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Enhances executive retention and commitment; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Efficiently uses shares resulting in lower share utilization; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Establishes a transparent cost basis. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During 2007,
the Committee awarded grants of restricted stock (or deferred stock units for participants in countries outside of the United States) to eligible employees, including our named executive officers. Restricted stock awards have been granted annually
at the Committee&#146;s first regularly scheduled meeting of the year, which typically takes place in late January or early February. Annual awards are granted on the date of the meeting and are based on the fair market value of Kraft&#146;s common
stock on that date. The fair market value is defined as the average of the high and low traded stock prices on the NYSE on the date of grant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Award ranges
are based on an analysis of competitive market practice, with the goal of providing awards with a value approximately equal to the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group. The range of award opportunities, expressed in terms of grant
value (calculated by multiplying the number of shares at grant by the fair market value of Kraft&#146;s common stock on the date of the grant), for the named executive officers as of January&nbsp;29, 2007, the date of the 2007 annual grant, were as
follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="86%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

awards granted to the named executive officers in 2007 were within the respective ranges presented above. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Actual stock award amounts in 2007 are presented
in this Proxy Statement in the Grants of Plan-Based Awards Table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">37 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Options.</I> Prior to 2007, the Committee had not granted new stock options to named executive officers since
our initial public offering (the &#147;IPO&#148;) in June 2001. Stock options granted to named executive officers at the time of the IPO were options to acquire Kraft common stock. Stock options granted prior to the IPO were options to acquire the
common stock of our previous parent company, Altria. All outstanding stock options have 10-year expiration periods, and many executive officers continue to hold options to acquire Kraft common stock and Altria common stock. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee granted Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld a special stock option award in 2007, which is discussed under &#147;Compensation Paid to Named Executive Officers in
2007.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As discussed below, other named executive officers received stock option awards to acquire Kraft common stock as a result of our spin-off from
Altria in March 2007, consistent with how all other Kraft employees who held Altria stock options at the time of the spin-off were treated. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment
of Stock Option Programs upon Completion of the Kraft Spin-off. </I>Upon the completion of our spin-off from Altria, Kraft and Altria each retained responsibility for our respective employees and compensation plans. At the time of the spin-off,
certain named executive officers held outstanding Altria stock options. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The holder of each outstanding option to purchase Altria common stock received the
following stock options with an aggregate intrinsic value (the difference between the exercise price of the options and the fair market value of the underlying stock) not greater than the intrinsic value of the original stock option: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A new Kraft stock option (issued by Kraft under its plan) to acquire a number of shares of Kraft common stock based on the spin-off ratio; and
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">An adjusted Altria stock option (issued by Altria) for the same number of shares of Altria common stock at a reduced exercise price. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The exercise prices for the new Kraft option and the adjusted Altria option were determined based on the closing market prices of Altria and Kraft common stock on
March&nbsp;30, 2007, the effective date of our spin-off. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Perquisites </U></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers receive limited perquisites, including a car allowance, a financial counseling allowance and, for the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer only, personal use of the corporate aircraft. For
reasons of security and personal safety, we require Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld to use our aircraft for both business and personal travel. Taxes on these perquisites are the sole responsibility of the executive officer. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">These perquisites are similar to those provided to named executive officers at many of the companies within the Compensation Survey Group. Accordingly, the Committee
believes that they are therefore necessary for retention and recruitment purposes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee periodically reviews perquisites to assure that they are
appropriate in light of Kraft&#146;s total compensation program and market practice. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Specific executive officer perquisites are listed in the footnotes to
the Summary Compensation Table. Other than these perquisites, executive officers receive the same benefits as other Kraft employees. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Post-Termination
Compensation </U></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Post-termination compensation consists of both separation pay and retirement benefits. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Change-in-Control Agreements.</I> We have no individual change-in-control agreements with any of our named executive officers, but we did implement a Change-In-Control
Plan (the &#147;CIC Plan&#148;) for senior executive officers in 2007. Based on our status as an independent public company following our spin-off from Altria on March&nbsp;30, 2007, the Committee believed that change-in-control arrangements were
appropriate for retention of senior executive officers. In addition, we amended our 2005 Performance Incentive Plan to assure that stock awards, including restricted stock and stock options, would not automatically vest upon a change-in-control.
Under the amended plan, restricted stock and stock options only vest upon a change-in-control if the participant is terminated without cause or resigns for good reason within two years following the change-in-control or if the acquiring entity does
not assume the awards (&#147;double trigger&#148;). We adopted the &#147;double-trigger&#148; to help assure that key personnel would be available to assist in the successful transition following a change-in-control. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">38 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The provisions in the CIC Plan are consistent with similar plans maintained by companies in the Compensation Survey Group
including eligibility, severance benefit levels and treatment of cash and equity incentive compensation. The separation payments are structured to help assure that key personnel, including our named executive officers, would be available to assist
in the successful transition following a change-in-control and provide a competitive level of severance protection if the executive officer is involuntarily terminated without cause following a change-in-control. In addition, under the CIC Plan,
Kraft will cover any excise taxes that may be triggered by separation payments paid to the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. However, excise taxes for all other participants will only be paid by Kraft if change-in-control separation payments
exceed 110% of the IRS-imposed cap of 2.99 times the base amount. To the extent that compensation does not exceed 110% of the IRS-imposed cap but does trigger excise tax payments, separation payments will be limited to the maximum amount that does
not trigger such excise tax amounts. This is done to minimize our expense for separation payments that do not significantly exceed the IRS-imposed cap limit. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The severance arrangements and other benefits provided for under the CIC Plan (as well as the equity treatment upon certain separations in the event of a change-in-control) are described under &#147;Executive Compensation Tables &#150;
Potential Payments Upon Termination or Change-in-Control.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Non-Change-in-Control Severance Agreements.</I> We have no individual severance
agreements with any of our actively employed named executive officers. For non-CIC Plan separations, we maintain a severance plan in the United States that provides for certain severance payments in the event of job elimination or a workforce
reduction. Similar plans are generally available in other countries where we have employees. The plans facilitate recruitment and retention, as most of the companies in the Compensation Survey Group offer similar benefits to their executives.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">From time to time, with Committee approval for named executive officers, we make separation payments to an executive officer if his or her employment is
terminated without cause for reasons that may or may not otherwise qualify for severance payments under one of our non-change-in-control severance plans. Typically, no payments or benefits are available or have accrued prior to an executive
officer&#146;s termination, nor do executive officers have rights to severance payments. These discretionary payments and benefits may be similar to or in excess of payments and benefits offered under a non-change-in-control severance plan. These
payments benefit Kraft because they are made in consideration for a general release of future claims against Kraft and the signing of non-compete, non-solicitation, non-disparagement and confidentiality agreements by the executive officers.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2007, we entered into a retirement agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Dollive. That agreement limited his ability to directly compete or solicit employees prior
to March&nbsp;1, 2009, released all claims against Kraft and assures that Mr.&nbsp;Dollive will keep all material information confidential. As consideration for these restrictive covenants, we replaced his restricted stock awards that were forfeited
upon his early retirement with deferred stock award units that vest in accordance with the original vesting schedule of his forfeited restricted stock awards. We provided this agreement to Mr.&nbsp;Dollive because of the significant value
represented by his agreement to a contractual non-compete, non-solicit, non-disparagement and confidentiality commitment received in exchange for the benefits provided by Kraft. This agreement is discussed in further detail under &#147;Executive
Compensation Tables &#150; Mr.&nbsp;Dollive&#146;s Retirement Agreement.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Additional information regarding payments typically made upon termination,
including a definition of key terms and a quantification of benefits that would be received by our named executive officers had termination occurred on December&nbsp;31, 2007, is presented under &#147;Executive Compensation Tables &#150; Potential
Payments Upon Termination or Change-in-Control.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Retirement Benefits.</I> Both tax-qualified and supplemental defined benefit retirement plans are
offered to executive officers, including the named executive officers, and vary by country. The Committee believes that these retirement benefits are important for retention and recruitment, as many of the companies in the Compensation Survey Group
offer similar programs. Accrued amounts and additional details of each of our defined benefit retirement programs offered to the named executive officers are presented in the 2007 Pension Benefits Table and the accompanying narrative to the table
under the heading &#147;Executive Compensation Tables.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s 2006 letter of employment provides her with an enhanced pension
benefit that bridges her service for the period of time that she was not employed by Kraft between 2004 and 2006. This enhanced pension benefit was part of a broader incentive program to help encourage her to return to Kraft. Additional details of
this enhanced pension benefit are presented in the 2007 Pension Benefits Table and the accompanying narrative to the table under the heading &#147;Executive Compensation Tables.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang participates in the Kraft Foods Switzerland Pension Fund. This pension plan is a contributory plan providing benefits related to the participant&#146;s years of accredited service and final covered
compensation. Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang participates in </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">39 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">the Kraft Foods Switzerland Pension Fund as a Swiss-based employee on an international assignment in the United States. This is the same plan that is
generally available to all eligible employees in Switzerland. Accrued amounts and additional details of Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang&#146;s retirement benefit programs are presented in the 2007 Pension Benefits Table and the accompanying narrative to the
table under &#147;Executive Compensation Tables.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee believes that both the U.S. tax-qualified and Supplemental Defined Contribution plans
are integral parts of our overall executive compensation program. The Supplemental Defined Contribution Plan is important because it encourages executive officers, including named executive officers, to save for retirement. The Committee believes
that our named executive officers should be able to defer the same percentage of their compensation, and receive the corresponding Kraft match, as all other employees, without regard to the compensation limit established by the Internal Revenue Code
for tax-qualified plan contributions. Accrued amounts and additional details of each of the non-qualified deferred compensation programs offered to named executive officers are presented in the 2007 Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation Table and the
accompanying narrative to the table under &#147;Executive Compensation Tables.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc53662_32"></A>Compensation Paid to Named Executive Officers in 2007 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Overview </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">There are no material differences in compensation policies with respect to each named executive officer, with the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Khosla, whose compensation is
higher due to benefits received in connection with his relocation and localization from New Zealand to the United States, and Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang, whose compensation appears higher due to tax equalization payments associated with his international
assignment in the United States. We designed each of the named executive officer&#146;s target compensation levels to be at the Compensation Survey Group&#146;s size-adjusted median. Compensation levels for the chief executive officer position at
the companies in the Compensation Survey Group generally exceed pay levels for other named executive officers. Similarly, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s compensation also exceeds that of our other named executive officers. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Many of the compensation actions taken in 2007 for the named executive officers were to position target total compensation closer to the size-adjusted median of the
Compensation Survey Group. Due to the change in our corporate structure in early 2007, specifically transitioning from a subsidiary of Altria to a free-standing, independent company, the roles of several senior executive officers were expanded. As a
result, target total compensation for those senior executive officers was increased. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Based on actual compensation actions taken for each of the named
executive officers in 2007, target total compensation for each of them remained slightly below the size-adjusted median for their respective positions. This reflects a combination of these named executive officers being newer in their roles as well
as mixed business results in recent years that have a direct impact on base salary increases and annual and long-term incentive awards during that period. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Below are the specific compensation actions for each of the named executive officers in 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base Salary Increase.</I> In 2007, the Committee approved a base salary increase for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld primarily to recognize her individual performance in 2006 and
to better align her salary with the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group. In 2006, the Committee considered the progress Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld made in developing and implementing her long-term strategy to bring Kraft back to
sustainable superior performance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Actual Annual Incentive.</I> In determining Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s annual incentive for 2007, the Committee
considered her performance relative to her financial and strategic guidelines for the year. Similar to our approach with respect to business unit ratings, individual performance measures are used merely as guidelines in the Committee&#146;s exercise
of discretion regarding Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s annual incentive award. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">40 </FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Discretionary cash flow is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to operating cash flow less capital expenditures. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, the Committee considered operating income margin and market share performance in their
assessment. In 2007, Kraft&#146;s results fell short of these two additional guidelines set by the Committee, which factored into the Committee&#146;s overall assessment of Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s 2007 performance. The shortfall on operating
income growth and margin was primarily driven by the unprecedented record-high commodity costs, particularly dairy costs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, in its assessment
of Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s 2007 performance, the Committee considered the following key strategic objectives, which were consistent with the goals that she discussed with investors at the beginning of 2007. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="73%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Key Strategic Objectives</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Assessment</B></FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upgrade talent in key management positions</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Introduced new leadership in key positions including Chief Financial Officer, Chief Marketing Officer, President Kraft International, and Executive Vice President Operations and Business
Services.</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Develop a three-year product pipeline to deliver growth targets</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Introduced significant new products in 2007 including <I>DiGiorno Ultimate</I> <I></I>pizza<I></I>, <I>Oreo Cakesters</I>, <I>Easy Mac</I>
<I>Cups</I>, <I>Oscar Mayer Deli Creations</I> <I></I>sandwiches,<I></I> <I>LiveActive </I>snacking and cottage cheeses, <I>Jacobs Sinnfonie</I>, and <I>Milka Tendres Moments</I>, which helped deliver a 30% increase in new product
revenue.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ten new product platforms are currently in development. </FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Transform the portfolio for sustainable growth</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Strengthened the portfolio with the acquisition of Groupe Danone&#146;s global biscuit business, which closed on November 30, 2007.</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Divested non-core businesses to improve business focus. Businesses divested included <I>Cream of
Wheat</I> and <I>Veryfine/Fruit2O</I>. Also announced the <I>Post</I> cereals transaction.</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Modify organizational structure/culture to deliver top-tier performance</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Began implementation of new operating structure, effective January 2008, to transition to self-contained business units with accountability for total
business results, shared services and a streamlined headquarters staff.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Complete transition to a free-standing company</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Managed share &#147;flow back&#148; effectively as measured by the following:</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Share price declined
less than expected immediately following the spin-off from Altria, despite 1.5 billion new shares being distributed from Altria to their shareholders and 87% share turnover (1.4 billion shares) in the first three months following our
spin-off.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Executed on $3.5 billion of a $5.0 billion board-authorized share repurchase program.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Repurchased 105.7 million shares at an average price of $33.13 as compared to an average
price during the repurchase period of $33.50.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Enhanced our leverage by issuing $6.5
billion of new long-term debt in two separate issuances with proceeds to be used to fund maturing long-term debt, share repurchases and a portion of the acquisition of Groupe Danone&#146;s global biscuit business.</FONT></P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">41 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a result of this assessment and the factors identified above, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld was awarded an annual incentive award
of $2,625,000, which reflects an amount above her target under the plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Awards.</I> Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld received two stock award grants in 2007.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-Height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As part of the annual stock award program, the Committee granted Ms. Rosenfeld a restricted stock
award of 144,280 shares. The grant value of this award was in-line with the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group. On May&nbsp;3, 2007, the Committee also granted her a non-qualified, performance-contingent stock option award
concurrent with her appointment to the additional position of Chairman. She was granted an option to purchase 300,000 shares of our common stock. The number of shares granted was determined by the Committee based on market-competitive information.
The combined grant value of these two awards was between the 50</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> and 75</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> percentile of the Compensation Survey Group. This type of award was granted to provide additional incentive for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld to increase shareholder value as the vesting of the award will only occur if certain
stock price hurdles are achieved. One-half of the shares under this performance-contingent stock option will vest only if the stock price maintains a trading price of $38.11 for at least 10 trading days. The remaining one-half of the award will vest
only if the stock price maintains a trading price of $41.43 for at least 10 trading days. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Mr.&nbsp;Dollive </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Actual Annual Incentive.</I> In 2007, in determining Mr.&nbsp;Dollive&#146;s actual annual incentive award and in connection with his retirement, the Committee
completed an initial assessment of Mr.&nbsp;Dollive&#146;s performance for the 2007 performance year in November and discussed his individual performance relative to goals set at the beginning of 2007. In determining a final award for
Mr.&nbsp;Dollive, the Committee considered his exceptional work in managing the financial transition and transformation associated with our March 2007 spin-off from Altria. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Awards.</I> In 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Dollive was granted a restricted stock award. His award was based on individual performance in the prior year, which was primarily focused on preparing for the financial
transition and transformation associated with our spin-off from Altria. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Mr.&nbsp;McLevish </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base Salary.</I> In setting Mr.&nbsp;McLevish&#146;s base salary as of his employment date, the Committee considered the size-adjusted median of the Compensation
Survey Group for his position and internal equity with Ms. Rosenfeld&#146;s other executive direct reports. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Sign-On Awards.</I>
Mr.&nbsp;McLevish&#146;s employment began on October&nbsp;1, 2007. On his employment date, the Committee granted him a sign-on restricted stock award of 43,350 shares, valued at $1,500,344, and a sign-on cash bonus of $500,000. These sign-on amounts
were awarded primarily to offset compensation awards from his previous employer that were forfeited when he resigned to accept his position at Kraft. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Actual Annual Incentive.</I> Based on his employment date, no specific performance guidelines were established at the beginning of the year. Mr.&nbsp;McLevish&#146;s 2007 annual incentive award was paid on a pro-rata basis, based on his
employment date, at target. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Mr.&nbsp;Khosla </U></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base
Salary.</I> In setting Mr.&nbsp;Khosla&#146;s base salary as of his employment date, the Committee considered the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group for his position and internal equity with Ms. Rosenfeld&#146;s other executive
direct reports. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Sign-On Awards.</I> Mr.&nbsp;Khosla&#146;s employment began on January&nbsp;22, 2007. On his employment date, the Committee granted him
a sign-on restricted stock award of 20,970 shares, valued at $750,307, and a sign-on cash bonus of $750,000. These sign-on amounts were awarded primarily to offset compensation awards from his previous employer that were forfeited when he resigned
to accept his position at Kraft. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Actual Annual Incentive.</I> Mr. Khosla&#146;s individual performance guidelines were primarily related to delivering
on 2007 business performance at Kraft International and developing a long-term strategy for sustainable growth. Specifically, Kraft International exceeded its organic revenue and discretionary cash flow guidelines, but fell short of its operating
income growth and operating income margin guidelines. In addition, the Committee considered other factors such as talent development both internally and externally and the successful acquisition of Groupe Danone&#146;s global biscuit business.
Mr.&nbsp;Khosla&#146;s 2007 annual incentive award was paid on a pro-rata basis, based on his employment date. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">42 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Awards.</I> In 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Khosla was granted a restricted stock award. His award was equal to the
size-adjusted median for his position as he was newly hired as of the date of grant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Relocation and Localization Benefits.</I> In addition,
Mr.&nbsp;Khosla&#146;s compensation for 2007 includes one-time relocation expenses associated with moving his family from New Zealand to the United States. These additional benefits were paid in connection with his offer letter and were important in
recruiting Mr.&nbsp;Khosla. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Mr.&nbsp;Searer </U></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base
Salary Increase.</I> In 2007, the Committee approved a base salary increase for Mr.&nbsp;Searer. The increase was primarily to position his salary closer to the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Actual Annual Incentive.</I> Mr.&nbsp;Searer&#146;s annual incentive target was increased from 80% to 90%, effective January&nbsp;31, 2007 and reflects the increased
scope of responsibilities he would be assuming following Kraft&#146;s spin-off from Altria. This increase in his target award increased his target total compensation opportunity to a level near the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey
Group. This change was also primarily to position his target annual incentive award closer to the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group. In determining his actual annual incentive award, the Committee considered his performance in
delivering on the 2007 plan for Kraft North America and improving marketing capability. Although organic revenue grew faster than expected, operating margin and market share were below expectations. Operating income was affected by unprecedented
commodity costs that could not be fully offset by pricing actions. Market share improved during the year as a result of the marketing investments made but still remained below expectations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Awards.</I> In 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Searer was granted a restricted stock award. His actual award reflected the size-adjusted median of the Compensation Survey Group
for his new position and his individual performance in 2006. With regard to his individual performance in 2006, the Committee considered financial results achieved within his scope of responsibility and considered the transition of responsibilities
to his successor following his promotion to President Kraft North America in September 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base Salary Increase.</I> In 2007, the Committee approved a base salary increase for Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang. Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang&#146;s salary increase was a reflection of
his individual performance in 2006 and was consistent with salary increases provided to other similarly situated executives based in Switzerland, his home country. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Actual Annual Incentive.</I> In determining his actual annual incentive award, the Committee considered his performance relative to delivering on productivity and restructuring savings. Specifically, Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang led the
restructuring of the Global Supply Chain function in our efforts to develop strategies that address both the challenges and opportunities of an ever-increasing global supplier base. He aggressively implemented strategies to optimize our total cost
structure, while improving service to our customers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Awards.</I> In 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang was granted a restricted stock award. His actual
award was based on his individual performance in 2006. Specifically, the Committee primarily considered achievements in supply chain efficiencies and other productivity initiatives led by Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang in 2006. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc53662_33"></A>Program Changes in 2008 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>2008 Annual Incentive Plan Changes </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Beginning January&nbsp;1, 2008, several key changes were made to the annual incentive plan. The changes are aimed at aligning the business strategies across the
enterprise by implementing a more formulaic approach to determine the business unit ratings. The three quantitative measures that will be measured, on an equal basis, are: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:3px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-Height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Organic revenue growth</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:3px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ongoing operating income growth</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT><FONT

SIZE="2">. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Organic revenue growth is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to net revenue, excluding the impact of currency, acquisitions and divestitures. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ongoing operating income is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to operating income, excluding items. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Discretionary cash flow is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to operating cash flow less capital expenditures. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">43 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee will still retain some discretion in awarding annual incentive awards; however, this design directly aligns
annual incentive awards to the performance related to those measures that will lead to sustainable superior total shareholder returns. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>2008 &#150; 2010
Long-Term Incentive Plan Design Changes </U></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We began a new performance cycle effective January&nbsp;1, 2008, which is scheduled to conclude on
December&nbsp;31, 2010. The Committee approved several changes relative to the 2007 &#150; 2009 performance cycle as follows: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P><DIV ALIGN="right">
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="93%" BORDER="0">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP ALIGN="center"> <P STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000;width:107pt" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2007 &#150; 2009 Performance Cycle</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP ALIGN="center"> <P STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000;width:107pt" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2008 &#150; 2010 Performance Cycle</B></FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ongoing operating income growth</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>(1)</SUP></FONT><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> was one of the four measures with a weighting of 20%</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Changed to ongoing earnings per share</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><SUP>(2)</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> growth with a weighting of 20% (other performance measures and weightings remain the same)</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="8"></TD>
<TD HEIGHT="8" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Payout will be in cash</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Payout will be in Kraft common stock at the end of the three-year program (will be a performance share
program)</FONT></P></TD></TR>
</TABLE></DIV> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ongoing operating income is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to operating income, excluding items. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ongoing earnings per share is a non-GAAP financial measure and is equal to diluted earnings per share, excluding items. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">These changes were implemented to further align the interests of our executive officers and shareholders by changing from a cash-based program to a performance
share-based program and rewarding executive officers on earnings per share growth. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><U>2008 Equity Program Changes </U></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2008, the Committee decided to grant equity in the form of both restricted stock and stock options. Restricted stock will now represent one-half of the economic value
delivered in equity, and the balance will be delivered in the form of stock options, based on a ratio of stock options to restricted stock of 4 to 1. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
rationale for reintroducing stock options into the long-term pay-mix is to further align executive compensation with shareholder returns. Stock option awards only deliver value to the executive officers if the stock price appreciates from the date
of grant and accordingly, executive officers only realize value when shareholders realize value. The combination of restricted stock and stock options balances the retention value of restricted stock with the performance aspect of stock options.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">To support the retention aspects of the program, the restricted stock will continue to vest 100% after three years, and the stock options will vest
one-third each year over three years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc53662_34"></A>Employment Agreements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a general matter, we do not utilize employment agreements. We did, however, agree to benefits,
greater than those generally made available to other employees, for Mr.&nbsp;Dollive upon his retirement from Kraft as consideration for Mr.&nbsp;Dollive&#146;s agreement to the restrictive covenants described above in &#147;Elements of Executive
Compensation - Post-Termination Compensation - Non-Change-in-Control Severance Agreements.&#148; For further information about Mr. Dollive&#146;s retirement agreement see &#147;Executive Compensation Tables &#150; Mr. Dollive&#146;s Retirement
Agreement.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc53662_35"></A>Policy With Respect To Qualifying Compensation for Tax Deductibility </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code limits
our ability to deduct compensation paid to covered employees, including several named executive officers, for tax purposes to $1.0 million annually. Covered employees include the principal executive officer and Kraft&#146;s next three highest paid
executive officers, other than Kraft&#146;s principal financial officer. This limitation does not apply to performance-based compensation, provided certain conditions are satisfied. For 2007, annual incentive awards and restricted stock grants
awarded to covered employees were subject to, and made in accordance with, performance-based compensation arrangements previously implemented, and were tax deductible. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee has taken appropriate actions to preserve the tax deductibility of annual cash incentive and long-term performance awards. The Committee has retained the discretion to authorize payments that may not be
tax deductible, if it believes that such payments are in the best interest of shareholders. For example, the Committee decided, based on benchmarking salaries of other chief executive officers in the Compensation Survey Group, to pay
Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld an annual base salary in excess of $1.0 million. Therefore, a portion of her salary was not tax deductible in 2007. In addition, a portion of each of the other covered employees income exceeded the $1.0 million tax deductibility
limit in 2007 because of other elements of their annual compensation. Specifically, compensation in excess of $1.0 million from a combination of base salary, restricted stock vesting proceeds, restricted stock dividends, sign-on bonuses and
perquisites were not deductible in 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">44 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc53662_36"></A>Policy on Recoupment of Executive Incentive Compensation in the Event of Certain Restatements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Board or an appropriate
committee of the Board may determine that, as a result of a restatement of Kraft&#146;s financial statements, an executive officer received more compensation than the executive officer would have received absent the incorrect financial statements.
Then, the Board or committee, in its discretion, may take such actions as it deems necessary or appropriate to address the events that gave rise to the restatement and to prevent its recurrence. Such actions may include, to the extent permitted by
applicable law: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Requiring the executive officer to repay some or all of any bonus or other incentive compensation paid; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Requiring the executive officer to repay any gains realized on the exercise of stock options or on the open-market sale of vested shares;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cancelling some or all of the executive officer&#146;s restricted stock or deferred stock awards and outstanding stock options; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Adjusting the executive officer&#146;s future compensation; or </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Terminating or initiating legal action against the executive officer, as the Board or the appropriate committee determines to be in Kraft&#146;s best interests.
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc53662_37"></A>Anti-Hedging Policy and Trading Restrictions </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our current policy limits the timing and types of transactions in Kraft
securities by Section&nbsp;16 officers. Among other restrictions, the policy: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Allows Section 16 officers to trade company securities only during window periods (following earnings releases) and only after they have pre-cleared transactions;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prohibits Section 16 officers from short-selling company securities or &#147;selling against the box&#148; (failing to deliver sold securities); and
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prohibits Section 16 officers (and any member of the Section 16 officer&#146;s family sharing the same household) from transactions in puts, calls or other
derivatives on Kraft securities on an exchange or in any other organized market, as well as any other derivative or hedging transactions on Kraft securities. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">45 </FONT></P>
